The completive-perfect-past in Kannada is expressed by the auxiliary verb ಹೊಂದಿದೆ (hondide). It is formed by adding the auxiliary verb to the past participle of the main verb. For example, the verb ಕಲಿಯಲು (kaliyalu) means "to learn". The completive-perfect-past form of this verb is ಕಲಿತಿದೆ (kalitide).

The completive-perfect-past aspect indicates that an action has been completed and its result is still relevant. The habitual aspect in Kannada is expressed using the verb ಹಬಿಚೂಅಲ (habichula). This verb is derived from the noun ಹಬ್ಬ (habba), which means "habit" or "custom." The habitual aspect is used to describe actions that are done regularly or on a repeated basis.

Here are some examples of the habitual aspect in Kannada:

    ನಾನು ಪ್ರತಿದಿನ ಕೆಲಸಕ್ಕೆ ಹೋಗುತ್ತೇನೆ (naanu prathidina kelsakke hoguddenu) - I go to work every day.
    ಅವರು ಬೆಳಿಗ್ಗೆ ಓದುತ್ತಾರೆ (avaru belagige odataru) - They read in the morning.
    ನಾವು ವಾರಕ್ಕೊಮ್ಮೆ ಚಿತ್ರಮಂದಿರಕ್ಕೆ ಹೋಗುತ್ತೇವೆ (naanu vaarakkommune chitramandirakke hoguddevenu) - We go to the cinema once a week.

The habitual aspect can also be used to describe actions that are done in the past, but that are still considered to be habitual. For example, you could say:

    ನಾನು ಚಿಕ್ಕವನಿದ್ದಾಗ ಪ್ರತಿದಿನ ಶಾಲೆಗೆ ಹೋಗುತ್ತಿದ್ದೆ (naanu chikkuvaniddagannu prathidina shaalege hoguddidene) - I used to go to school every day when I was a child.

The habitual aspect is a versatile grammatical feature that can be used to express a variety of meanings. By understanding how to use it, you can make your Kannada more expressive and nuanced.

pattern: The subjunctive mood is used under certain circumstances in subordinate clauses, typically for actions that are subjective or otherwise uncertain.

“कृपया रेलिंग से दुरी बनाये रखें” – “Please keep a distance from the railing”

The implied agency is “by us”. Interrogative Subjunctive  Imperative Subjunctive (Polite) : First Person Imperative अन्दर चलें – “Let’s go inside” जाते हैं – “Let’s go” मैं आपको याद दिला दूं कि उसने क्या किया है – “Let me remind you what he has done”  Second Person Imperative उनको बताएँ – “Please tell them”

खुश रहो – “May you remain happy”

आपके दुश्मान मर जाएं – “May your enemies die!” To Express Nescience Often idioms involving the subjunctive mood like न जाने “no one knows” or कौन जाने “who knows” will be used.

pattern: Subjunctive mood is used for conditional sentences (Can be used with almost all tenses and moods)   यदि + खाता, पीता, सोता तो जाता, आता(verbal form in past)  In Hindi, the words अगर and यदि are optional, but तो is always required. The presence of तो between two clauses is enough to signal a conditional sentence. (Examples of conditional in various tenses can be seen here https://hindilanguage.info/hindi-grammar/conditional-sentences/) In colloquial Hindi, the relative pronoun जो may be used instead of अगर or यदि.
example: यदि मैं पढ़ता तो विद्वान हो जाता। अगर मै बाहर जाता तो मै भीग जाता। Extra sentences आपको हिन्दुस्तानी खाना अच्छा लगता है तो आपको मेरे घर आना चाहिए खाना खाने के लिए – “If you like Indian food then you should come to my house to eat” Conditional Present and Future: Present tense condition present tense consequence अगर आपको हिंदी आती है तो आप यह अख़बार पढ़ सकते हैं – “If you understand Hindi, then you can read this newspaper” : Present tense condition future tense consequence अगर आप रोज़ दौड़ते हैं तो आप उस दौड़ में बहुत आसानी से दौड़ सकेंगे – “If you run daily then you will be able to run in that race very easily”,   Future Condition, Future Consequence अगर आप भारत आयेंगे तो मैं आपको घुमाऊँगी/दिखाऊंगी – “If you come to India, I’ll show you around” Simple Past Condition, Future Consequence अगर तुमने ठीक से हिंदी भाषा पढ़ी तो तुम इसको सीख जाओगे – “If you study the Hindi language properly then you will learn it”
